name: 1598_C. Delete Two Elements
description:
Monocarp has got an array a consisting of n integers. Let's denote k as the mathematic mean of these elements (note that it's possible that k is not an integer). 

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements (i. e. sum divided by n).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k.

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements (i. e. sum divided by n).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k.

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a). Consider edge cases where the array is too small or all elements are identical. Make sure to handle arrays with fewer than three elements gracefully.

Monocarp has an array a with n elements. The mean, k, of these elements is calculated by dividing the sum of all elements by the number of elements. Monocarp wants to remove two elements from this array such that the mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still k. We need to find the number of pairs [i, j] where i < j, and removing the elements at these positions keeps the mean of the array unchanged. It's crucial to handle cases where the array has fewer than three elements, as well as when all elements are the same.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin

Monocarp has an array a of n integers, and the mean k is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements. He wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still k. Calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that deleting the elements at these positions keeps the mean of the remaining elements equal to k, and handle edge cases where the array is too small or all elements are identical.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin
completions:
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    if mean == 0:
        # If the mean is zero, any pair of elements can be deleted
        return n * (n - 1) // 2
    
    freq = {}
    for num in arr:
        freq[num] = freq.get(num, 0) + 1
    
    pairs_count = 0
    
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            new_n = n - 2
            new_mean = new_sum / new_n
            
            if new_mean == mean:
                pairs_count += 1
    
    return pairs_count

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_pairs(n, arr):
    """
    Calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted,
    the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is still equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean
    of n elements of the original array a).

    Args:
        n (int): The number of elements in the array.
        arr (list): The list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        int: The number of pairs of positions [i, j] such that if the elements on these positions are deleted,
             the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is still equal to k.
    """
    # Calculate the mean of the entire array
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean_value = total_sum / n

    # If the array has fewer than 3 elements, return 0
    if n < 3:
        return 0

    # Initialize the count of pairs
    count = 0

    # Iterate through all possible pairs of indices
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            # Calculate the sum of the array without the elements at indices i and j
            new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            # Calculate the new mean
            new_mean = new_sum / (n - 2)
            # Check if the new mean is equal to the original mean
            if new_mean == mean_value:
                count += 1

    return count

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of elements in the array
    n = int(input())
    # Read the array elements
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    # Calculate and print the result
    result = calculate_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    pairs = 0
    count = {}
    
    # Count the number of times the difference between an element and the mean appears
    for num in arr:
        diff = num - mean
        if diff in count:
            count[diff] += 1
        else:
            count[diff] = 1
    
    # Iterate through the array and check for pairs that can be deleted to maintain the mean
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            diff = (arr[i] + arr[j]) - mean * 2
            if diff in count and count[diff] > 0:
                pairs += 1
    
    return pairs

# Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def find_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    
    if all(x == arr[0] for x in arr):
        # Calculate the number of pairs when all elements are the same
        return n * (n - 1) // 2
    
    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            if new_sum / (n - 2) == mean:
                count += 1
    return count

# Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = find_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def find_pairs_to_remove(n, arr):
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n

    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if arr[i] != arr[j]:
                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                if new_sum / (n - 2) == mean:
                    count += 1
    return count

# Read input
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = find_pairs_to_remove(n, arr)
    print(result)

    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if (total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]) / (n - 2) == mean:

from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    if n < 3:
        return -1
    if all(x == arr[0] for x in arr):
        return -1
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if i != j:
                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                new_mean = new_sum / (n - 2)
                if new_mean == mean:
                    count += 1
    return count

from typing import List
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs_to_delete(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    if n < 3:
        return 0
    
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    count = 0
    
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if i != j:
                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                new_mean = new_sum / (n - 2)

    return count

# Provide the Interface

    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs_to_delete(n, arr)

from typing import List
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(arr: List[int], mean_val: float) -> int:
    n = len(arr)
    count = 0
    
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            temp_arr = arr[:i] + arr[i+1:j] + arr[j+1:]
            if sum(temp_arr) / (n - 2) == mean_val:
                count += 1
    return count

def main():
    t = int(input())
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
        mean_val = sum(arr) / n
        result = calculate_pairs(arr, mean_val)
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
plans:
requirement analysis:
The primary requirement is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] such that deleting the elements at these positions keeps the mean unchanged. The solution must handle edge cases, including arrays with fewer than three elements and cases where all elements are identical. The input size can be large, so the solution must be optimized for performance.
requirement pool:
- Implement a function to calculate the mean of the array.
- Create a function to find pairs of positions [i, j] that can be deleted without changing the mean.
- Optimize the solution for large inputs to ensure it runs efficiently within the given constraints.
- Handle edge cases where the array has fewer than three elements or all elements are identical.
To solve this problem, we will use Python due to its efficiency and ease of handling large datasets. The approach involves calculating the mean of the array and then finding pairs of indices whose deletion does not alter the mean. We will use a dictionary to keep track of the frequency of each element to avoid recalculating the sum and mean for each pair of indices.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
 # [core concept]
    'mathematical mean': the sum of all elements divided by the number of elements in the array.
    Explanation: The mean (average) of a set of numbers is calculated by dividing the sum of the numbers by the count of the numbers. In this problem, we need to find pairs of indices whose deletion does not change the mean of the remaining elements.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'more than': indicates that we need to find pairs of indices where the deletion does not change the mean.
    Explanation: For example, if we have an array [1, 2, 3, 4], the mean is (1+2+3+4)/4 = 2.5. If we delete elements at indices 1 and 3 (resulting in [1, 3]), the new mean is (1+3)/2 = 2, which is equal to the original mean.

# [degree adverb] 
    'largest': indicates that we need to find the largest possible pairs of indices that can be deleted without changing the mean.
    Explanation: In the context of the problem, 'largest' refers to the maximum number of pairs of indices that can be deleted to maintain the mean.

# [code logic]
    (check if there are steps should be considered simultaneously)
    To implement the solution, we need to:
    1. Calculate the mean of the array.
    2. Use a dictionary to count the frequency of each element.
    3. Iterate through all possible pairs of indices (i, j) where i < j.
    4. For each pair, calculate the new mean after deleting the elements at indices i and j.
    5. Count the number of pairs that result in the same mean as the original array.

# [edge case] 
    Edge case 1: Array with fewer than three elements
    search([1, 2]) = 0
    Explanation: Since there are fewer than three elements, it's impossible to delete any two elements and still have an array with a mean.

    Edge case 2: All elements in the array are identical
    search([5, 5, 5]) = 1
    Explanation: If all elements are the same, deleting any two elements will not change the mean. There is only one pair of indices to consider: [0, 1] or [0, 2] or [1, 2].

    Edge case 3: Array with all elements being zero
    search([0, 0, 0]) = 0
    Explanation: The mean is 0, and deleting any two elements will change the mean. There are no pairs that can be deleted without altering the mean.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The logic provided in the plan should be sufficient to handle these cases gracefully.

 # [core concept]
    'mean': the average value of a set of numbers
    'removal': the act of taking out elements from a set
    'maintain': keep the same value or condition

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'more than': indicates a comparison where one quantity is greater than another
    'at least as many times': means the same or more

# [degree adverb] 
    'largest': the biggest or greatest in size, amount, or degree

# [code logic]
    (check if there are steps should be considered simultaneously)

# [edge case] 
    search([1, 1, 1]) = 0
    explanation: All elements are the same, so removing any two elements will change the mean.
    search([2, 2, 3, 3, 3]) = 4
    explanation: There are two pairs that can be removed to keep the mean unchanged: [0, 2] and [1, 2].

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge case. We can directly return 0 for the case where all elements are the same.

# [code logic]
    def search(lst):
        total_sum = sum(lst)
        n = len(lst)
        mean = total_sum / n

        count = 0
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(i+1, n):
                if lst[i] != lst[j]:
                    new_sum = total_sum - lst[i] - lst[j]
                    if new_sum / (n - 2) == mean:
                        count += 1
        return count

# [edge case] 
    search([1, 1, 1]) = 0
    expected output: 0
    Explanation: All elements are the same, so removing any two elements will change the mean.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge case. We can directly return 0 for the case where all elements are the same.

 # [core concept]
    'mathematic mean': the average value of a set of numbers, calculated by dividing the sum of the numbers by the count of the numbers.
    Explanation: In this problem, we need to find pairs of positions [i, j] such that deleting the elements at these positions does not change the mean of the remaining elements. The mean of the entire array is calculated and then we check each pair to see if their deletion maintains this mean.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'more than': indicates that we need to find pairs of positions where the deletion does not change the mean.
    Explanation: We need to ensure that after deleting two elements, the mean of the remaining elements is still equal to the original mean.

# [degree adverb] 
    'largest': not applicable in this context as we are looking for pairs that maintain the mean, not the largest elements.
    Explanation: We are not focusing on finding the largest elements but rather on maintaining the mean through pair deletion.

# [code logic]
    (check if there are steps should be considered simultaneously)
    To solve this problem, we need to:
    1. Calculate the mean of the entire array.
    2. Iterate through all possible pairs [i, j] where i < j.
    3. Check if deleting the elements at positions i and j maintains the mean.
    4. Count the number of such pairs.

# [edge case] 
    Edge case 1: Array with fewer than three elements.
    Example: [1, 2]
    Expected output: 0
    Explanation: Since there are fewer than three elements, it's impossible to delete two elements and maintain the mean.

    Edge case 2: All elements in the array are identical.
    Example: [5, 5, 5]
    Expected output: 3
    Explanation: Any two elements can be deleted, and the mean will remain the same. There are three possible pairs: [0, 1], [0, 2], and [1, 2].

    Edge case 3: No pair can be deleted to maintain the mean.
    Example: [1, 2, 3]
    Expected output: 0
    Explanation: There is no pair of elements that can be deleted to maintain the mean of the array.

    def main():
        t = int(input())
        for _ in range(t):
            n = int(input())
            a = list(map(int, input().split()))
            if n < 3:
                print(0)
                continue
            # Continue with the main logic for larger arrays

    This code checks if the array has fewer than three elements and immediately outputs 0 if true, as no pairs can be deleted to maintain the mean.
examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
